titleInfo.title: Letter from Frank Babin to Henrietta Lauzin, 1864 May 13

mods.note: Frank Babin enlisted as a private in the Confederate Army and was assigned to Company I, which was a part of the 2nd Louisiana Cavalry. Henrietta Lauzin (b.1842) was the daughter of Dr. Jean Lauzin and Leocadie Teetzman and the great-great-granddaughter of Antonio de Gras.
mods.abstract: Frank Babin, Cotton Press Prison, New Orleans, writes to Henrietta Lauzin. He begins in a joking manner, stating 'How do you like the name of our magnificent and most secluded- quiet and safe hotel?' He then informs her that he will buy Francis Palms' pipe, but states 'I do not like to trust it to the person Frank requested me to- as I am afraid he will make use of it- for his own special benefit.' Additionally, he comments on his living conditions stating, 'Our quarters are pretty good- but too much crowded. There is a good deal of sickness.' Before closing he states that he has enclosed a ring and asks Henrietta to deliver it to Miss Marie.
mods.accessCondition: Physical rights are retained by the LSU Libraries. Copyright of the original material is retained in accordance with U.S. copyright laws. Permission to reproduce this image must be requested through the Special Collections Division, Louisiana State University Libraries.
Please submit an LSU Special Collections reference ticket at https://askus.lib.lsu.edu/special for any questions or comments about this digital object.
mods.note: Gras-Lauzin Family Papers, Mss. 5, Louisiana and Lower Mississippi Valley Collections, LSU Libraries, Baton Rouge, La.

recordInfo.recordOrigin: Transformed into MODS from extended Dublin Core by the LDL Development Team at Louisiana State University.
